item.title: From meteor shower to comet: Astronomical events to look forward to in Jan 2025 - The Times of India
item.description:
Astronomical Events to Look Forward to in January 2025

Publication Date: January 2025

Source: Unknown

January 2025 brings a dazzling lineup of astronomical events that will captivate both avid sky-watchers and casual stargazers.

  • January 3: Venus and Moon conjunction visible after sunset.
  • January 3-4: Quadrantid Meteor Shower peaks with 60 to 200 meteors per hour.
  • January 4: Occultation of Saturn by the Moon observable in select locations.
  • January 4: Earth at Perihelion, closest point to the Sun.
  • January 9-10: Venus reaches its greatest elongation.
  • January 13: Wolf Moon, marking the full moon of January.
  • January 16: Mars at opposition, appearing brighter in the sky.
  • January 29: New Moon, ideal for stargazing.
"January’s full moon, known as Wolf Moon, has great cultural significance for many cultures."

In summary, this January offers numerous celestial events that provide excellent opportunities for stargazing and appreciating the wonders of our universe.

item.title: Theory of relativity, quantum physics key to explaining Big Bang, says scientist - The Hindu
item.description:
Theory of relativity, quantum physics key to explaining Big Bang, says scientist

Published: January 02, 2025, Source: The Hindu

A combination of Albert Einstein’s theory of relativity and quantum physics may help explain the expansion of the universe from a singular entity, according to P. Ajith, an astrophysicist with the International Centre for Theoretical Sciences in Bengaluru. He presented this topic during a lecture at the Regional Science Centre and Planetarium in Kozhikode.

  • The primordial atom theory, proposed by Georges Lemaitre, is more of a narrative than a scientific fact.
  • History of cosmic understanding spans from Copernicus to Newton, shaping modern science and technology.
  • Einstein’s theory redefined gravity as a consequence of space-time effects rather than a force.
“The primordial atom is just a way of explaining what might have happened. To understand what happened then, we need to combine Einstein’s theory of relativity with quantum physics.” - P. Ajith

The integration of these scientific principles might offer profound insights into the universe's origins and evolution, highlighting the importance of continued exploration in physics.

item.title: 6 Stunning Pictures Of Quasars and Black Holes Taken By NASA Hubble Space Telescope - Times Now
item.description:
6 Stunning Pictures Of Quasars and Black Holes Taken By NASA Hubble Space Telescope

Publication Date: Jan 2, 2025 Source: Times Now

This article highlights six breathtaking images of quasars and black holes captured by the NASA Hubble Space Telescope, showcasing the beauty and complexity of these astronomical phenomena.

  • Markarian 231: Two black holes in a close orbital dance illuminating the galaxy’s center.
  • Markarian 817: A spiral galaxy with blue star clusters surrounding an active supermassive black hole.
  • Quasar 3C 273: One of the closest quasars, its light took 2.5 billion years to reach Earth.
  • NGC 4438: A black hole exhibiting chaotic behavior with massive outflows of hot gas.
  • Quasar Tsunamis: Showcases the immense energy produced by quasars.
"Quasars produce immense energy, powered by a supermassive black hole consuming surrounding matter."

This collection of images not only illustrates the stunning visuals provided by the Hubble Space Telescope but also emphasizes the crucial role that these celestial bodies play in the universe.

item.title: Mars, Venus, Saturn and Jupiter to align the night sky in January: Here's the exact date and time - India TV News
item.description:
January Planet Parade: Mars, Venus, Saturn, and Jupiter Align in the Night Sky

Publication Date: January 2025

Source: India TV News

This January, stargazers and astronomers will witness a spectacular alignment of four major planets: Mars, Venus, Saturn, and Jupiter, with the best view on January 17 and 18.

  • Mars will reach its brightest point on January 15-16, sitting prominently in the constellation Gemini.
  • Venus and Saturn will appear unusually close together, separated by only a few finger widths.
  • Jupiter will complete the planetary lineup, shining brightly in the sky.
  • Uranus and Neptune will also be visible for those with telescopes.
  • This event is referred to as a 'planet parade' by astronomers, highlighting its rarity and significance.
Mars’ opposition not only offers a visual delight but also provides ideal conditions for spacecraft launches and interplanetary missions.

This alignment not only captivates observers but also holds potential significance for future space exploration endeavors.

item.title: 2025's first meteor shower 'Quadrantid' to light up the skies: How to watch in India? - DNA India
item.description:
2025's first meteor shower 'Quadrantid' to light up the skies: How to watch in India?

Publication Date: January 2, 2025 | Source: DNA India

The Quadrantid meteor shower, one of the most exciting astronomical events of 2025, will light up the night sky on 3 and 4 January. Active since 27 December, it promises a spectacular start to the New Year with meteors visible across the sky.

  • The Quadrantids have a brief peak, lasting only a few hours.
  • During the peak, you could see between 60 to 200 meteors per hour, depending on weather conditions, according to NASA.
  • This meteor shower originates from the asteroid 2003 EH1.
  • The best viewing times in India will be during the early hours of January 3 and 4.
  • Expected rates of meteors during the peak are between 80 to 120 per hour.
“To make the experience even better, the planetarium will set up telescopes for public viewing.” - Sumit Srivastava, senior scientific officer at the Indira Gandhi Planetarium

This meteor shower is a thrilling way to start 2025, offering a beautiful display for night sky watchers in India.

item.title: 5 top space exploration milestones of 2024 - Hindustan Times
item.description:
5 Top Space Exploration Milestones of 2024

Publication Date: January 2, 2025, Source: Hindustan Times

The year 2024 saw amazing milestones in space exploration, from groundbreaking discoveries to historic spacewalks.

  • NASA's Perseverance rover made significant discoveries on Mars, including organic molecules.
  • SpaceX's Polaris Dawn mission marked the first spacewalk conducted by civilians.
  • India successfully launched its small satellite, EOS-5, with the SSLV.
  • NASA's Parker Solar Probe made the closest dive to the sun, setting a new record.
  • Overall, 2024 was a landmark year with milestones shaping the future of space exploration.
“This discovery reignited discussions about the possibility of extraterrestrial life on Mars and beyond.”

2024 was a transformative year for space exploration, with innovations and findings reshaping our understanding of the cosmos.

item.title: Transforming the Moon Into Humanity’s First Space Hub - WIRED
item.description:
Transforming the Moon Into Humanity’s First Space Hub

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Wired

This year marks a turning point in humanity’s relationship with the moon, as we begin to lay the foundations for a permanent presence on its surface, paving the way for our natural satellite to become an industrial hub.

  • Three critical elements for developing a lunar economy: access, refueling capabilities, and profitable enterprises.
  • SpaceX's Starship, designed for reuse and capable of delivering significant payloads to the moon, will demonstrate its capabilities in 2025.
  • Blue Origin’s Blue Moon lander will mark its maiden flight in 2025, crucial for establishing lunar infrastructure.
  • Nasa’s Artemis II mission intends to carry a crew around the moon in late 2025, a significant step towards lunar exploration.
  • The Lunar Gateway will be launched in 2025, acting as a logistics hub for lunar missions.
  • Starpath is developing a lunar gas station to support sustainable fuel production for return journeys to Earth.
“As these technologies take off, the moon will no longer be just a distant, desolate place. It will become the gateway to humanity’s future in space.”

This initiative paints an optimistic picture of the moon’s potential, transforming it into a stepping stone for future space exploration.

item.title: First meteor shower of 2025 is coming. How to catch the Quadrantids - India Today
item.description:
First Meteor Shower of 2025: How to Catch the Quadrantids

Published On: Jan 2, 2025 | Source: India Today

As the new year unfolds, stargazers are in for a treat with the Quadrantid meteor shower, which peaks on January 3-4, 2025. This celestial event marks the first significant meteor shower of the year, offering a dazzling display of fireballs streaking across the night sky.

  • The Quadrantids are a unique meteor shower, originating from the asteroid 2003 EH1.
  • They peak at 60 to 120 meteors per hour under ideal conditions.
  • The meteor shower is visible particularly between 3:00 AM and 5:00 AM local time.
  • Quadrantids typically do not leave long trails but can be bright fireballs.
  • The meteor shower will remain active until January 16, 2025.
Nasa's William Cooke notes that while Quadrantids typically do not leave long trails, their heads can appear as bright fireballs.

Finding a dark location away from city lights is essential for optimal viewing. Minimal moonlight interference offers an excellent opportunity for celestial enthusiasts to enjoy this spectacular event.

item.title: An alien signal hit Earth in 2022. Astronomers have now found its original source - India Today
item.description:
Astronomers Discover Source of Alien Signal Detected on Earth in 2022

Published On: Jan 2, 2025 by Sibu Kumar Tripathi

Astronomers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) have made major advancements in tracing the origins of fast radio bursts (FRBs). This study reveals that FRB 20221022A originated from a distance of approximately 200 million light-years, likely from within 10,000 kilometers of a rotating neutron star.

  • The research utilized data from the Canadian Hydrogen Intensity Mapping Experiment (CHIME), boosting the detection rate of FRBs.
  • FRBs emit intense bursts of radio signals for milliseconds, with discoveries dating back to 2007.
  • Scintillation analysis helped researchers ascertain the signal's origin more accurately.
  • Findings indicate FRBs may stem from chaotic magnetic environments around neutron stars, called magnetars.
“In these environments of neutron stars, the magnetic fields are really at the limits of what the universe can produce.” - Kenzie Nimmo

This research expands our understanding of FRBs, with astronomers anticipating further revelations about their origins and behavior.

item.title: Gravity Always Wins: A chronicle of 2024's space mishaps - DNA India
item.description:
Gravity Always Wins: A chronicle of 2024's space mishaps

Publication Date & Source: January 2, 2025, DNA India

This article reflects on the various challenges and blunders that marked 2024's space exploration efforts, highlighting both serious issues and amusing mishaps along the way.

  • Florida Man's home struck by falling ISS debris
  • Japan's SLIM lander lands upside down but survives
  • IM-1 lander nicknamed “Odie” tops over after touchdown
  • Peregrine lunar lander fails shortly after launch
  • NASA cancels VIPER, intended for lunar polar exploration
  • Delayed opening of asteroid sample container by NASA
  • Boeing's Starliner causes astronauts to remain stranded on the ISS
  • SpaceX faces regulatory investigations and environmental concerns
  • Russia's missile test creates a massive crater instead of demonstrating its capabilities
  • Alien signal theory debunked when attributed to a truck's vibrations
“There was a loud noise,” Alejandro Otero said about the ISS debris incident, “and it almost hit my son.”

The article illustrates the unpredictable nature of space exploration, reminding us of the humor and humanity behind our attempts to conquer the final frontier.

item.title: NASA warning: Two aeroplane-sized asteroids approaching Earth today – key details, timing, and impact - The Times of India
item.description:
NASA warning: Two aeroplane-sized asteroids approaching Earth today – key details, timing, and impact

Publication Date: January 2, 2024 | Source: Times of India

NASA has announced that two asteroids, 2024 YF7 and 2024 YR9, are set to pass near Earth. While their approach is of interest, there is no immediate danger to the planet.

  • Asteroid 2024 YF7 is about 78 feet in diameter and will pass at a distance of 2,080,000 miles at 2:53 a.m. on January 2, 2024.
  • Asteroid 2024 YR9 is slightly smaller, at 76 feet, and will pass at the same distance but at a higher speed of 46,338 miles per hour.
  • Both asteroids are significant for studying the early solar system and improving planetary defense strategies.
“Monitoring asteroids plays a critical role in ensuring that we are prepared to address challenges that may come our way as we continue to explore and learn about the universe.”

While these asteroids pose no threat, their study is crucial for understanding our solar system's history and enhancing our readiness for potential future threats.

item.title: ​8 Beautiful Unseen Deep Space Pictures Captured By NASA​ - Times Now
item.description:
8 Beautiful Unseen Deep Space Pictures Captured By NASA

Published on: Jan 2, 2025 | Source: Times Now

This article presents stunning photographs taken by NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope, showcasing deep space phenomena in breathtaking detail.

  • Features eight extraordinary deep space images captured by NASA.
  • Covers various celestial bodies and phenomena, including galaxies, star formations, and nebulae.
  • Highlights interesting facts about each image, providing scientific context.
“This collection represents some of the most beautiful and unseen aspects of deep space captured by NASA.”

These images not only provide insight into the universe's mysteries but also inspire awe and curiosity about space exploration.

item.title: Planet parade, meteor showers and more: Here's celestial calender of 2025 - The Economic Times
item.description:
Planet Parade, Meteor Showers and More: Here's Celestial Calendar of 2025

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Not specified

As 2025 approaches, astronomy enthusiasts can look forward to numerous celestial events including supermoons and a spectacular planet parade.

Key Points:

  • Six-planet parade begins in January, with a seven-planet lineup including Mercury in February.
  • Total lunar eclipse on March 14, followed by a partial solar eclipse two weeks later.
  • Three supermoons in October, November, and December, with November's supermoon being particularly close to Earth.
  • Northern and southern lights expected due to geomagnetic storms.
  • Popular meteor showers such as the Perseids and Geminids peaking in August and December.
"People should go out and see them sometime during the next many weeks. I certainly will," - Bruce Betts, Chief Scientist of the Planetary Society.

2025 promises to be an exciting year for skywatchers, with numerous opportunities to witness incredible celestial phenomena.

item.title: 2025’s first meteor shower 'Quadrantid' to light up the skies: When to watch in India - The Times of India
item.description:
2025’s First Meteor Shower 'Quadrantid' to Light Up the Skies: When to Watch in India

Published on: January 1, 2025   |   Source: Times of India

The Quadrantid meteor shower is set to be visible in India, with optimal viewing conditions allowing stargazers to witness this celestial event. The shower usually peaks in early January, providing a spectacular sight for astronomy enthusiasts.

  • The Quadrantids peak around January 3-4, 2025.
  • Best viewing conditions are expected from midnight to dawn.
  • Dark skies away from city lights are ideal for spotting the meteors.
  • This meteor shower can produce over 100 meteors per hour at its peak under perfect conditions.
“The Quadrantids are renowned for their bright fireballs and are a favorite among skywatchers.”

In conclusion, the Quadrantid meteor shower promises to be a must-see event for astronomy enthusiasts in India, offering a chance to witness one of the year's significant meteor displays.

item.title: Four Lunar and Solar eclipses in 2025: Check dates, timings and visibility in Odisha - OTV News
item.description:
Four Lunar and Solar Eclipses in 2025: Dates, Timings, and Visibility in Odisha

Publication Date: Not specified Source: OTV News

The year 2025 will feature four major eclipses, including two partial solar and two total lunar eclipses. Among these, only one total lunar eclipse will be visible from India.

  • The first total lunar eclipse is on March 14, not visible in India.
  • The first partial solar eclipse occurs on March 29, also not visible in India.
  • The notable lunar eclipse on September 7 will be fully observable from India, appearing blood-red.
  • The final partial solar eclipse will occur from September 21 to 22, not visible from India, focusing on Australia and Antarctica.
“The lunar eclipse on September 7 and 8 will be visible in India. It can be witnessed with the naked eye and will last for a long period, being visible until 12:22 AM.” - Suvendu Pattnaik

The upcoming eclipses present a unique opportunity for Indian observers, especially the September lunar eclipse, which promises a spectacular view.

item.title: Five amazing images of Nebula captured by NASA Hubble Telescope - India.com
item.description:
Five Amazing Images of Nebula Captured by NASA Hubble Telescope

Date & Source: January 01, 2025, India.com

The NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope has provided us with a stunning collection of nebula images. These nebulae, located in distant galaxies, offer a glimpse into the cosmos.

  1. Veil Nebula: A small section of the Veil Nebula observed by Hubble.
  2. Eagle Nebula: A billowing tower of cold gas and dust rising from a stellar nursery in the Eagle Nebula.
  3. NGC 1501: A complex planetary nebula located in the constellation of Camelopardalis, showcased in a new image from Hubble's Wide Field Planetary Camera 2.
  4. Iris Nebula: A close-up of an area in the northwest region of the large Iris Nebula, clogged with cosmic dust.
  5. Lagoon Nebula: A colorful image of the Lagoon Nebula, captured to celebrate Hubble's 28th anniversary in space.

item.title: NASA probe safely completes closest-ever approach to Sun - Kashmir Reader
item.description:
NASA's Parker Solar Probe Makes Closest Approach to Sun

Date: 2022-12-30, Source: NASA

On December 24, NASA’s Parker Solar Probe successfully completed the closest-ever approach to the Sun, reaching a distance of 3.8 million miles (6.1 million kilometers) from the Sun's surface. The probe, traveling at speeds up to 430,000 mph (692,000 kph), endured temperatures up to 1,800 degrees Fahrenheit (982 degrees Celsius) in the Sun’s outer atmosphere, the corona.

  1. The Parker Solar Probe, launched in 2018, aims to study the Sun and help scientists understand why the Sun's outer atmosphere is hundreds of times hotter than its surface.
  2. The spacecraft uses gravity-assist flybys of Venus to inch closer to the Sun with each orbit.
  3. Data from the probe might help answer what drives the solar wind and better understand solar energetic particles.
“This mission allows us to get closer to the Sun than ever before, helping scientists understand how the solar wind forms, why the Sun’s outer layer heats up to millions of degrees, and how energetic particles accelerate near light speed.” - NASA

The Parker Solar Probe is expected to send detailed telemetry data about its latest journey on January 1.
